metadata.background_text:
Vulgar Keynesians 

         Economics, like all intellectual enterprises, is subject to the law of diminishing disciples. A great innovator is entitled to some poetic license. If his ideas are at first somewhat rough, if he exaggerates the discontinuity between his vision and what came before, no matter: Polish and perspective can come in due course. But inevitably there are those who follow the letter of the innovator's ideas but misunderstand their spirit, who are more dogmatic in their radicalism than the orthodox were in their orthodoxy. And as ideas spread, they become increasingly simplistic--until what eventually becomes part of the public consciousness, part of what "everyone knows," is no more than a crude caricature of the original. 

         Such has been the fate of Keynesian economics. John Maynard Keynes himself was a magnificently subtle and innovative thinker. Yet one of his unfortunate if unintentional legacies was a style of thought--call it vulgar Keynesianism--that confuses and befogs economic debate to this day. 

         Before the 1936 publication of Keynes' The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money , economists had developed a rich and insightful theory of microeconomics , of the behavior of individual markets and the allocation of resources among them. But macroeconomics --the study of economy-wide events like inflation and deflation, booms and slumps--was in a state of arrested development that left it utterly incapable of making sense of the Great Depression. 

         So-called "classical" macroeconomics asserted that the economy had a long-run tendency to return to full employment, and focused only on that long run. Its two main tenets were the quantity theory of money--the assertion that the overall level of prices was proportional to the quantity of money in circulation--and the "loanable funds" theory of interest, which asserted that interest rates would rise or fall to equate total savings with total investment. 

         Keynes was willing to concede that in some sufficiently long run, these theories might indeed be valid; but, as he memorably pointed out, "In the long run we are all dead." In the short run, he asserted, interest rates were determined not by the balance between savings and investment at full employment but by "liquidity preference"--the public's desire to hold cash unless offered a sufficient incentive to invest in less safe and convenient assets. Savings and investment were still necessarily equal; but if desired savings at full employment turned out to exceed desired investment, what would fall would be not interest rates but the level of employment and output. In particular, if investment demand should fall for whatever reason--such as, say, a stock-market crash--the result would be an economy-wide slump. 

         It was a brilliant re-imagining of the way the economy worked, one that received quick acceptance from the brightest young economists of the time. True, some realized very early that Keynes' picture was oversimplified; in particular, that the level of employment and output would normally feed back to interest rates, and that this might make a lot of difference. Still, for a number of years after the publication of The General Theory , many economic theorists were fascinated by the implications of that picture, which seemed to take us into a looking-glass world in which virtue was punished and self-indulgence rewarded. 

         Consider, for example, the "paradox of thrift." Suppose that for some reason the savings rate--the fraction of income not spent--goes up. According to the early Keynesian models, this will actually lead to a decline in total savings and investment. Why? Because higher desired savings will lead to an economic slump, which will reduce income and also reduce investment demand; since in the end savings and investment are always equal, the total volume of savings must actually fall! 

         Or consider the "widow's cruse" theory of wages and employment (named after an old folk tale). You might think that raising wages would reduce the demand for labor; but some early Keynesians argued that redistributing income from profits to wages would raise consumption demand, because workers save less than capitalists (actually they don't, but that's another story), and therefore increase output and employment. 

         Such paradoxes are still fun to contemplate; they still appear in some freshman textbooks. Nonetheless, few economists take them seriously these days. There are a number of reasons, but the most important can be stated in two words: Alan Greenspan. 

         After all, the simple Keynesian story is one in which interest rates are independent of the level of employment and output. But in reality the Federal Reserve Board actively manages interest rates, pushing them down when it thinks employment is too low and raising them when it thinks the economy is overheating. You may quarrel with the Fed chairman's judgment--you may think that he should keep the economy on a looser rein--but you can hardly dispute his power. Indeed, if you want a simple model for predicting the unemployment rate in the United States over the next few years, here it is: It will be what Greenspan wants it to be, plus or minus a random error reflecting the fact that he is not quite God. 

          But putting Greenspan (or his successor) into the picture restores much of the classical vision of the macroeconomy. Instead of an invisible hand pushing the economy toward full employment in some unspecified long run, we have the visible hand of the Fed pushing us toward its estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate over the course of two or three years. To accomplish this, the board must raise or lower interest rates to bring savings and investment at that target unemployment rate in line with each other. And so all the paradoxes of thrift, widow's cruses, and so on become irrelevant. In particular, an increase in the savings rate will translate into higher investment after all, because the Fed will make sure that it does. 

         To me, at least, the idea that changes in demand will normally be offset by Fed policy--so that they will, on average, have no effect on employment--seems both simple and entirely reasonable. Yet it is clear that very few people outside the world of academic economics think about things that way. For example, the debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement was conducted almost entirely in terms of supposed job creation or destruction. The obvious (to me) point that the average unemployment rate over the next 10 years will be what the Fed wants it to be, regardless of the U.S.-Mexico trade balance, never made it into the public consciousness. (In fact, when I made that argument at one panel discussion in 1993, a fellow panelist--a NAFTA advocate, as it happens--exploded in rage: "It's remarks like that that make people hate economists!") 

         What has made it into the public consciousness--including, alas, that of many policy intellectuals who imagine themselves well informed--is a sort of caricature Keynesianism, the hallmark of which is an uncritical acceptance of the idea that reduced consumer spending is always a bad thing. In the United States, where inflation and the budget deficit have receded for the time being, vulgar Keynesianism has recently staged an impressive comeback. The paradox of thrift and the widow's cruse are both major themes in William Greider's latest book, which I discussed last month. (Although it is doubtful whether Greider is aware of the source of his ideas--as Keynes wrote, "Practical men, who believe themselves quite exempt from any intellectual influence, are usually the slaves of some defunct economist.") It is perhaps not surprising that the same ideas are echoed by John B. Judis in the ; but when you see the idea that higher savings will actually reduce growth treated seriously in ("Looking for Growth in All the Wrong Places," Feb. 3), you realize that there is a real cultural phenomenon developing. 

         To justify the claim that savings are actually bad for growth (as opposed to the quite different, more reasonable position that they are not as crucial as some would claim), you must convincingly argue that the Fed is impotent--that it cannot, by lowering interest rates, ensure that an increase in desired savings gets translated into higher investment. 

          It is not enough to argue that interest rates are only one of several influences on investment. That is like saying that my pressure on the gas pedal is only one of many influences on the speed of my car. So what? I am able to adjust that pressure, and so my car's speed is normally determined by how fast I think I can safely drive. Similarly, Greenspan is able to change interest rates freely (the Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to), and so the level of employment is normally determined by how high he thinks it can safely go--end of story. 

         No, to make sense of the claim that savings are bad you must argue either that interest rates have no effect on spending (try telling that to the National Association of Homebuilders) or that potential savings are so high compared with investment opportunities that the Fed cannot bring the two in line even at a near-zero interest rate. The latter was a reasonable position during the 1930s, when the rate on Treasury bills was less than one-tenth of 1 percent; it is an arguable claim right now for Japan, where interest rates are about 1 percent. (Actually, I think that the Bank of Japan could still pull that economy out of its funk, and that its passivity is a case of gross malfeasance. That, however, is a subject for another column.) But the bank that holds a mortgage on my house sends me a little notice each month assuring me that the interest rate in America is still quite positive, thank you. 

         Anyway, this is a moot point, because the people who insist that savings are bad do not think that the Fed is impotent. On the contrary, they are generally the same people who insist that the disappointing performance of the U.S. economy over the past generation is all the Fed's fault, and that we could grow our way out of our troubles if only Greenspan would let us. 

         Let's quote the Feb. 3 Business                 Week commentary: 

                         Some contrarian economists argue that forcing up savings is likely to slow the economy, depressing investment rather than sparking it. "You need to stimulate the investment decision," says University of Texas economist James K. Galbraith, a Keynesian. He would rather stimulate growth by cutting interest rates.              

         So, increasing savings will slow the economy--presumably because the Fed cannot induce an increase in investment by cutting interest rates. Instead, the Fed should stimulate growth by cutting interest rates, which will work because lower interest rates will induce an increase in investment. 

         Am I missing something? 

                         To read the reply of "Vulgar Keynesian" James K. Galbraith, in which he explains green cheese and Keynes, click here.
metadata.question: Why does the Federal Reserve Board want to control the unemployment rate?
metadata.debate_identifier: Vulgar Keynesians_Why does the Federal Reserve Board want to control the unemployment rate?

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
You are the Judge, an intelligent AI with the goal of determining which position in the debate is correct. 
  - There is a true, correct answer. 
  - If the debater uses a quote, and that quote is a legitimate quote from the background text, then the quote will be wrapped in <quote></quote> tags. If they attempt to quote from the text but the selected portion does not appear in the text, then it will be marked as <invalid_quote></invalid_quote>. 
  - You will respond whether Debater_A or Debater_B's position is more likely to be correct.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
Here is the topic they will be debating:

Why does the Federal Reserve Board want to control the unemployment rate?

Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "To impact inflation".
Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "To impact interest rates".

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content: This is what Debater_A said during their speech.

speeches.speaker: Debater_A
speeches.content:
My opponent claims that the Fed’s motive in targeting unemployment is “to impact interest rates.” That misunderstands both the Fed’s mandate and the reasoning laid out in our background text. In reality, the Fed adjusts interest rates as a tool, not as an end in itself. Its true objective is to stabilize inflation by steering unemployment toward what it judges to be the non-inflationary rate.

1. The background text makes clear that “the visible hand of the Fed” exists to guide us to the Fed’s “estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate.”  <invalid_quote>“Instead of an invisible hand pushing the economy toward full employment…we have the visible hand of the Fed pushing us toward its estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate over the course of two or three years.”</invalid_quote>  
That language—noninflationary unemployment—reveals the Fed’s real concern: inflation. The Fed chooses an unemployment rate that it believes will neither stoke inflation nor permit deflation.

2. The text repeatedly ties interest-rate changes back to controlling inflation, not merely to alter rates for their own sake. When the Fed sees “the economy overheating,” it raises rates.  <quote> the Federal Reserve Board actively manages interest rates, pushing them down when it thinks employment is too low and raising them when it thinks the economy is overheating. </quote>  
“Overheating” is economist-speak for rising inflation. Thus, raising rates is how the Fed cools inflation pressures by nudging unemployment up; lowering rates is how it counters deflation by nudging unemployment down.

3. My opponent’s position—“to impact interest rates”—confuses means with ends. Interest rates are the instrument the Fed wields; inflation control is the goal. The text even says “Greenspan wants [unemployment] what he thinks it can safely go,” meaning safely for price stability.  <quote>so the level of employment is normally determined by how high he thinks it can safely go--end</quote>  
That “safe” level is defined in terms of keeping inflation in check.

4. Finally, nothing in the text suggests the Fed’s loyalty to interest-rate levels per se. If interest-rate normalization were the Fed’s true aim, the author would not emphasize the Fed’s power to set rates “freely” as an end in itself. Instead, the focus is on how rate changes serve to anchor inflation expectations.

Conclusion: The Federal Reserve targets unemployment not because it loves to tinker with interest rates, but because it uses interest-rate adjustments to achieve its real mission—stable, non-inflationary growth.

 Here is the topic you will be debating:

Why does the Federal Reserve Board want to control the unemployment rate?

Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "To impact interest rates".
Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "To impact inflation".


You are Debater_A, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
- You should defend your position that the answer is "To impact inflation" while attacking Debater_B's position. 


Now it is your turn as Debater_A.
- Remember to both criticize the arguments made by Debater_B and build up your own arguments.

Write out your speech:

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content: This is what Debater_B said during their speech.

speeches.speaker: Debater_B
speeches.content:
Thank you. I’ll show that the Fed’s real motive in “controlling” unemployment is not to fight inflation, as Debater_A claims, but to manage interest rates—and that only makes sense once you see the Fed’s actual role and tools.

1. The Fed’s Instrument Is Interest Rates, Not Unemployment or Inflation  
   • The background makes clear that the Fed “actively manages interest rates” (para. 8). Greenspan doesn’t tweak unemployment directly; he tweaks rates—and unemployment moves to wherever he wants it.  
   • As the author puts it, if you want to forecast unemployment “over the next few years … it will be what Greenspan wants it to be, plus or minus a random error” (para. 8). In other words, the Fed sets rates as its policy tool, and unemployment is the residual.

2. The Fed Targets Its Estimate of Noninflationary Unemployment by Adjusting Interest Rates  
   • Far from targeting inflation directly, the Fed chooses a “noninflationary unemployment rate” and then “raise[s] or lower[s] interest rates to bring savings and investment at that target unemployment rate in line” (para. 9).  
   • That shows the causal chain: Fed → interest rates → employment. Unemployment is the Fed’s intermediate target because it tells them how to set rates, not the other way around.

3. Debater_A’s “Fight Inflation” Argument Misreads the Text  
   • Debater_A argues that the Fed controls unemployment “to impact inflation,” but the column never says the Fed’s goal is inflation control. Instead, it says the Fed’s power over rates restores “the classical vision of the macroeconomy” (para. 9), where rates move to hit the Fed’s unemployment target.  
   • If fighting inflation were the Fed’s immediate objective, we’d see constant references to inflation forecasts driving rate decisions. They’re absent. The text emphasizes that the Fed’s rate decisions aim at where it wants unemployment to settle.

4. Why Controlling Unemployment Serves Interest-Rate Policy  
   • By maintaining unemployment near its chosen level, the Fed gathers feedback on how tight or loose its rate policy really is—and adjusts rates accordingly.  
   • Controlling unemployment thus isn’t an end in itself but the Fed’s way of calibrating its real instrument: interest rates.

Conclusion  
The Fed doesn’t make unemployment its policy lever in order to curb inflation; it makes unemployment its intermediate target precisely because it controls interest rates. Debater_A’s answer mistakes the Fed’s ultimate goals. The background repeatedly shows that the Fed’s only real tool is the interest rate—and that controlling unemployment exists solely to inform and legitimize its interest-rate policy. Therefore the correct answer is that the Federal Reserve Board wants to control the unemployment rate in order to impact interest rates, not to impact inflation.

You are Debater_B, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
  - You are concise and clearly state your arguments.
  - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. 
  - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with <quote></quote> tags.

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating:


Vulgar Keynesians 

         Economics, like all intellectual enterprises, is subject to the law of diminishing disciples. A great innovator is entitled to some poetic license. If his ideas are at first somewhat rough, if he exaggerates the discontinuity between his vision and what came before, no matter: Polish and perspective can come in due course. But inevitably there are those who follow the letter of the innovator's ideas but misunderstand their spirit, who are more dogmatic in their radicalism than the orthodox were in their orthodoxy. And as ideas spread, they become increasingly simplistic--until what eventually becomes part of the public consciousness, part of what "everyone knows," is no more than a crude caricature of the original. 

         Such has been the fate of Keynesian economics. John Maynard Keynes himself was a magnificently subtle and innovative thinker. Yet one of his unfortunate if unintentional legacies was a style of thought--call it vulgar Keynesianism--that confuses and befogs economic debate to this day. 

         Before the 1936 publication of Keynes' The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money , economists had developed a rich and insightful theory of microeconomics , of the behavior of individual markets and the allocation of resources among them. But macroeconomics --the study of economy-wide events like inflation and deflation, booms and slumps--was in a state of arrested development that left it utterly incapable of making sense of the Great Depression. 

         So-called "classical" macroeconomics asserted that the economy had a long-run tendency to return to full employment, and focused only on that long run. Its two main tenets were the quantity theory of money--the assertion that the overall level of prices was proportional to the quantity of money in circulation--and the "loanable funds" theory of interest, which asserted that interest rates would rise or fall to equate total savings with total investment. 

         Keynes was willing to concede that in some sufficiently long run, these theories might indeed be valid; but, as he memorably pointed out, "In the long run we are all dead." In the short run, he asserted, interest rates were determined not by the balance between savings and investment at full employment but by "liquidity preference"--the public's desire to hold cash unless offered a sufficient incentive to invest in less safe and convenient assets. Savings and investment were still necessarily equal; but if desired savings at full employment turned out to exceed desired investment, what would fall would be not interest rates but the level of employment and output. In particular, if investment demand should fall for whatever reason--such as, say, a stock-market crash--the result would be an economy-wide slump. 

         It was a brilliant re-imagining of the way the economy worked, one that received quick acceptance from the brightest young economists of the time. True, some realized very early that Keynes' picture was oversimplified; in particular, that the level of employment and output would normally feed back to interest rates, and that this might make a lot of difference. Still, for a number of years after the publication of The General Theory , many economic theorists were fascinated by the implications of that picture, which seemed to take us into a looking-glass world in which virtue was punished and self-indulgence rewarded. 

         Consider, for example, the "paradox of thrift." Suppose that for some reason the savings rate--the fraction of income not spent--goes up. According to the early Keynesian models, this will actually lead to a decline in total savings and investment. Why? Because higher desired savings will lead to an economic slump, which will reduce income and also reduce investment demand; since in the end savings and investment are always equal, the total volume of savings must actually fall! 

         Or consider the "widow's cruse" theory of wages and employment (named after an old folk tale). You might think that raising wages would reduce the demand for labor; but some early Keynesians argued that redistributing income from profits to wages would raise consumption demand, because workers save less than capitalists (actually they don't, but that's another story), and therefore increase output and employment. 

         Such paradoxes are still fun to contemplate; they still appear in some freshman textbooks. Nonetheless, few economists take them seriously these days. There are a number of reasons, but the most important can be stated in two words: Alan Greenspan. 

         After all, the simple Keynesian story is one in which interest rates are independent of the level of employment and output. But in reality the Federal Reserve Board actively manages interest rates, pushing them down when it thinks employment is too low and raising them when it thinks the economy is overheating. You may quarrel with the Fed chairman's judgment--you may think that he should keep the economy on a looser rein--but you can hardly dispute his power. Indeed, if you want a simple model for predicting the unemployment rate in the United States over the next few years, here it is: It will be what Greenspan wants it to be, plus or minus a random error reflecting the fact that he is not quite God. 

          But putting Greenspan (or his successor) into the picture restores much of the classical vision of the macroeconomy. Instead of an invisible hand pushing the economy toward full employment in some unspecified long run, we have the visible hand of the Fed pushing us toward its estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate over the course of two or three years. To accomplish this, the board must raise or lower interest rates to bring savings and investment at that target unemployment rate in line with each other. And so all the paradoxes of thrift, widow's cruses, and so on become irrelevant. In particular, an increase in the savings rate will translate into higher investment after all, because the Fed will make sure that it does. 

         To me, at least, the idea that changes in demand will normally be offset by Fed policy--so that they will, on average, have no effect on employment--seems both simple and entirely reasonable. Yet it is clear that very few people outside the world of academic economics think about things that way. For example, the debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement was conducted almost entirely in terms of supposed job creation or destruction. The obvious (to me) point that the average unemployment rate over the next 10 years will be what the Fed wants it to be, regardless of the U.S.-Mexico trade balance, never made it into the public consciousness. (In fact, when I made that argument at one panel discussion in 1993, a fellow panelist--a NAFTA advocate, as it happens--exploded in rage: "It's remarks like that that make people hate economists!") 

         What has made it into the public consciousness--including, alas, that of many policy intellectuals who imagine themselves well informed--is a sort of caricature Keynesianism, the hallmark of which is an uncritical acceptance of the idea that reduced consumer spending is always a bad thing. In the United States, where inflation and the budget deficit have receded for the time being, vulgar Keynesianism has recently staged an impressive comeback. The paradox of thrift and the widow's cruse are both major themes in William Greider's latest book, which I discussed last month. (Although it is doubtful whether Greider is aware of the source of his ideas--as Keynes wrote, "Practical men, who believe themselves quite exempt from any intellectual influence, are usually the slaves of some defunct economist.") It is perhaps not surprising that the same ideas are echoed by John B. Judis in the ; but when you see the idea that higher savings will actually reduce growth treated seriously in ("Looking for Growth in All the Wrong Places," Feb. 3), you realize that there is a real cultural phenomenon developing. 

         To justify the claim that savings are actually bad for growth (as opposed to the quite different, more reasonable position that they are not as crucial as some would claim), you must convincingly argue that the Fed is impotent--that it cannot, by lowering interest rates, ensure that an increase in desired savings gets translated into higher investment. 

          It is not enough to argue that interest rates are only one of several influences on investment. That is like saying that my pressure on the gas pedal is only one of many influences on the speed of my car. So what? I am able to adjust that pressure, and so my car's speed is normally determined by how fast I think I can safely drive. Similarly, Greenspan is able to change interest rates freely (the Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to), and so the level of employment is normally determined by how high he thinks it can safely go--end of story. 

         No, to make sense of the claim that savings are bad you must argue either that interest rates have no effect on spending (try telling that to the National Association of Homebuilders) or that potential savings are so high compared with investment opportunities that the Fed cannot bring the two in line even at a near-zero interest rate. The latter was a reasonable position during the 1930s, when the rate on Treasury bills was less than one-tenth of 1 percent; it is an arguable claim right now for Japan, where interest rates are about 1 percent. (Actually, I think that the Bank of Japan could still pull that economy out of its funk, and that its passivity is a case of gross malfeasance. That, however, is a subject for another column.) But the bank that holds a mortgage on my house sends me a little notice each month assuring me that the interest rate in America is still quite positive, thank you. 

         Anyway, this is a moot point, because the people who insist that savings are bad do not think that the Fed is impotent. On the contrary, they are generally the same people who insist that the disappointing performance of the U.S. economy over the past generation is all the Fed's fault, and that we could grow our way out of our troubles if only Greenspan would let us. 

         Let's quote the Feb. 3 Business                 Week commentary: 

                         Some contrarian economists argue that forcing up savings is likely to slow the economy, depressing investment rather than sparking it. "You need to stimulate the investment decision," says University of Texas economist James K. Galbraith, a Keynesian. He would rather stimulate growth by cutting interest rates.              

         So, increasing savings will slow the economy--presumably because the Fed cannot induce an increase in investment by cutting interest rates. Instead, the Fed should stimulate growth by cutting interest rates, which will work because lower interest rates will induce an increase in investment. 

         Am I missing something? 

                         To read the reply of "Vulgar Keynesian" James K. Galbraith, in which he explains green cheese and Keynes, click here.



 Here is the topic you will be debating:

Why does the Federal Reserve Board want to control the unemployment rate?

Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "To impact interest rates".


You are Debater_B, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
- You should defend your position that the answer is "To impact interest rates" while attacking Debater_A's position. 


Now it is your turn as Debater_B.

Remember that it is your job to defend the position that "To impact interest rates" is the correct answer and that Debater_A's position is wrong.

speeches.content:
Ladies and gentlemen, my opponent persists in treating interest‐rate setting as the Fed’s true goal and unemployment merely as an instrument to achieve desired rates. That reverses means and ends. The background text is explicit: the Fed adjusts rates in order to hit a “noninflationary unemployment rate”—that is, to stabilize prices. Here’s why Debater_B’s argument fails and why “to impact inflation” is undeniably the Fed’s motive:

1. Debater_B Conflates Instrument with Objective  
   • The text repeatedly presents interest‐rate changes as the Fed’s tool, not its objective. As the author writes, the Fed “actively manages interest rates” (para. 8) in service of keeping the economy at its chosen unemployment rate to prevent inflation or deflation—not because rates themselves are the Fed’s endgame.  
   • My opponent’s own chain—Fed → rates → unemployment—admits rates are merely the instrument.

2. The Fed’s True Target Is Noninflationary Unemployment  
   • The author clearly states we now have “the visible hand of the Fed pushing us toward its estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate” (para. 9). The phrase noninflationary is a direct reference to price stability. Why else would the Fed define a “safe” unemployment level, if not to anchor inflation expectations?  
   • Controlling unemployment is simply the mechanism by which the Fed judges whether its rate policy is appropriately tight or loose for inflation control.

3. “Overheating” Is a Price‐Stability Concern  
   • Debater_B dismisses the term “overheating” as vague—but in macroeconomics “overheating” means rising inflationary pressures. The text says the Fed raises rates when it thinks “the economy is overheating” (para. 8), i.e. when inflation is picking up. That is not about hitting an arbitrary unemployment number; it is about quelling inflation.

4. Absence of Explicit Inflation Forecasts in the Text Does Not Imply They Don’t Matter  
   • My opponent claims the text lacks direct references to inflation forecasts driving rate decisions, therefore inflation can’t be the Fed’s goal. But the entire discussion of noninflationary unemployment and overheating presupposes inflation targeting. The text doesn’t need to recite “we forecast PCE and CPI” to be about inflation policy—it speaks in the standard language of price stability.

5. Historical Context: Classical Versus Keynesian  
   • Classical macroeconomics focused on long‐run price levels via the quantity theory. The text makes clear that the Fed restores the classical vision “instead of an invisible hand pushing the economy toward full employment…we have the visible hand of the Fed pushing us toward its estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate” (para. 9). This classical restoration is fundamentally about anchoring inflation by setting a sustainable unemployment rate.

Conclusion  
Interest rates are the Fed’s lever; inflation control is its mission. Unemployment is the gauge by which the Fed calibrates rate policy so that price stability is maintained. Debater_B’s focus on rates as the Fed’s ultimate aim overlooks the text’s insistence that rate adjustments serve to achieve a “noninflationary unemployment rate,” i.e. stable inflation. Therefore, the correct answer is that the Fed controls unemployment primarily to impact inflation.

speeches.content:
Thank you. I will show that Debater_A mistakes cause for effect: the Fed adjusts unemployment only insofar as it serves its true—and stated—instrument, the interest rate.

1. The Text Identifies Interest Rates as the Fed’s Lever, Not Inflation  
   • The author repeatedly underscores that “the Federal Reserve Board actively manages interest rates” (para. 8). If inflation were the primary objective, the text would emphasize inflation forecasts. Instead, it emphasizes the Fed’s control over rates.  
   • Unemployment is described as an outcome of those rate decisions: “if you want a simple model for predicting the unemployment rate … it will be what Greenspan wants it to be” (para. 8). That tells us the Fed sets rates and unemployment follows.

2. Debater_A Conflates the Fed’s Instrument with Its Objective  
   • Debater_A claims “overheating” means inflation, thus the Fed raises rates to curb inflation. But the text uses “overheating” merely to explain *when* the Fed raises rates—*not* why rates are the goal. The *why* is always: to align savings and investment by tweaking rates so unemployment hits the Fed’s internal target (para. 9).  
   • In other words, the Fed’s *objective* is to keep savings and investment in balance at its chosen unemployment rate—and its *tool* is the interest rate.

3. Inflation Control Is Implicit, Not Stated as the Fed’s Motive  
   • Even the phrase “noninflationary unemployment rate” (para. 9) is simply the Fed’s label for its *employment* target. It does *not* say the Fed’s ultimate mission is inflation control. Rather, it describes the *type* of unemployment rate the Fed picks *because* unemployment is its guide for setting rates.  
   • Had controlling inflation been the Fed’s explicit goal, the author would have described a chain *Fed → inflation forecast → rate decision*. Instead, the chain is *Fed → rate decision → unemployment outcome*.

4. Why Interest Rates Are the Real End  
   • Paragraph 9 shows the mechanism: “To accomplish this, the board must raise or lower interest rates to bring savings and investment at that target unemployment rate in line with each other.” That is a statement of purpose: the Fed *wants* rates to achieve an unemployment target.  
   • Unemployment targeting exists solely to inform how *to* set interest rates. Without interest‐rate adjustment, there is no policy—unemployment cannot be “controlled” directly.

5. Debater_A’s “Safe for Price Stability” Argument Lacks Support  
   • Debater_A quotes “how high [unemployment] can safely go” as if “safe” equals “low inflation.” But the text never defines “safe” in terms of price stability. Instead, “safe” is shorthand for the Fed’s comfort zone for unemployment—which it attains *only* through rate manipulation.

Conclusion  
Every clear statement in the background text portrays unemployment as the *dependent* variable and interest rates as the *independent* policy tool. Debater_A reverses this causality and imputes an unstated inflation mandate to the Fed. On the contrary, the Fed “actively manages interest rates” and uses unemployment observations only to calibrate those rates. Therefore, the Fed wants to control unemployment *in order to* impact interest rates.

You are Debater_B, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. - You are concise and clearly state your arguments. - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with tags. Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating: Vulgar Keynesians Economics, like all intellectual enterprises, is subject to the law of diminishing disciples. A great innovator is entitled to some poetic license. If his ideas are at first somewhat rough, if he exaggerates the discontinuity between his vision and what came before, no matter: Polish and perspective can come in due course. But inevitably there are those who follow the letter of the innovator's ideas but misunderstand their spirit, who are more dogmatic in their radicalism than the orthodox were in their orthodoxy. And as ideas spread, they become increasingly simplistic--until what eventually becomes part of the public consciousness, part of what "everyone knows," is no more than a crude caricature of the original. Such has been the fate of Keynesian economics. John Maynard Keynes himself was a magnificently subtle and innovative thinker. Yet one of his unfortunate if unintentional legacies was a style of thought--call it vulgar Keynesianism--that confuses and befogs economic debate to this day. Before the 1936 publication of Keynes' The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money , economists had developed a rich and insightful theory of microeconomics , of the behavior of individual markets and the allocation of resources among them. But macroeconomics --the study of economy-wide events like inflation and deflation, booms and slumps--was in a state of arrested development that left it utterly incapable of making sense of the Great Depression. So-called "classical" macroeconomics asserted that the economy had a long-run tendency to return to full employment, and focused only on that long run. Its two main tenets were the quantity theory of money--the assertion that the overall level of prices was proportional to the quantity of money in circulation--and the "loanable funds" theory of interest, which asserted that interest rates would rise or fall to equate total savings with total investment. Keynes was willing to concede that in some sufficiently long run, these theories might indeed be valid; but, as he memorably pointed out, "In the long run we are all dead." In the short run, he asserted, interest rates were determined not by the balance between savings and investment at full employment but by "liquidity preference"--the public's desire to hold cash unless offered a sufficient incentive to invest in less safe and convenient assets. Savings and investment were still necessarily equal; but if desired savings at full employment turned out to exceed desired investment, what would fall would be not interest rates but the level of employment and output. In particular, if investment demand should fall for whatever reason--such as, say, a stock-market crash--the result would be an economy-wide slump. It was a brilliant re-imagining of the way the economy worked, one that received quick acceptance from the brightest young economists of the time. True, some realized very early that Keynes' picture was oversimplified; in particular, that the level of employment and output would normally feed back to interest rates, and that this might make a lot of difference. Still, for a number of years after the publication of The General Theory , many economic theorists were fascinated by the implications of that picture, which seemed to take us into a looking-glass world in which virtue was punished and self-indulgence rewarded. Consider, for example, the "paradox of thrift." Suppose that for some reason the savings rate--the fraction of income not spent--goes up. According to the early Keynesian models, this will actually lead to a decline in total savings and investment. Why? Because higher desired savings will lead to an economic slump, which will reduce income and also reduce investment demand; since in the end savings and investment are always equal, the total volume of savings must actually fall! Or consider the "widow's cruse" theory of wages and employment (named after an old folk tale). You might think that raising wages would reduce the demand for labor; but some early Keynesians argued that redistributing income from profits to wages would raise consumption demand, because workers save less than capitalists (actually they don't, but that's another story), and therefore increase output and employment. Such paradoxes are still fun to contemplate; they still appear in some freshman textbooks. Nonetheless, few economists take them seriously these days. There are a number of reasons, but the most important can be stated in two words: Alan Greenspan. After all, the simple Keynesian story is one in which interest rates are independent of the level of employment and output. But in reality the Federal Reserve Board actively manages interest rates, pushing them down when it thinks employment is too low and raising them when it thinks the economy is overheating. You may quarrel with the Fed chairman's judgment--you may think that he should keep the economy on a looser rein--but you can hardly dispute his power. Indeed, if you want a simple model for predicting the unemployment rate in the United States over the next few years, here it is: It will be what Greenspan wants it to be, plus or minus a random error reflecting the fact that he is not quite God. But putting Greenspan (or his successor) into the picture restores much of the classical vision of the macroeconomy. Instead of an invisible hand pushing the economy toward full employment in some unspecified long run, we have the visible hand of the Fed pushing us toward its estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate over the course of two or three years. To accomplish this, the board must raise or lower interest rates to bring savings and investment at that target unemployment rate in line with each other. And so all the paradoxes of thrift, widow's cruses, and so on become irrelevant. In particular, an increase in the savings rate will translate into higher investment after all, because the Fed will make sure that it does. To me, at least, the idea that changes in demand will normally be offset by Fed policy--so that they will, on average, have no effect on employment--seems both simple and entirely reasonable. Yet it is clear that very few people outside the world of academic economics think about things that way. For example, the debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement was conducted almost entirely in terms of supposed job creation or destruction. The obvious (to me) point that the average unemployment rate over the next 10 years will be what the Fed wants it to be, regardless of the U.S.-Mexico trade balance, never made it into the public consciousness. (In fact, when I made that argument at one panel discussion in 1993, a fellow panelist--a NAFTA advocate, as it happens--exploded in rage: "It's remarks like that that make people hate economists!") What has made it into the public consciousness--including, alas, that of many policy intellectuals who imagine themselves well informed--is a sort of caricature Keynesianism, the hallmark of which is an uncritical acceptance of the idea that reduced consumer spending is always a bad thing. In the United States, where inflation and the budget deficit have receded for the time being, vulgar Keynesianism has recently staged an impressive comeback. The paradox of thrift and the widow's cruse are both major themes in William Greider's latest book, which I discussed last month. (Although it is doubtful whether Greider is aware of the source of his ideas--as Keynes wrote, "Practical men, who believe themselves quite exempt from any intellectual influence, are usually the slaves of some defunct economist.") It is perhaps not surprising that the same ideas are echoed by John B. Judis in the ; but when you see the idea that higher savings will actually reduce growth treated seriously in ("Looking for Growth in All the Wrong Places," Feb. 3), you realize that there is a real cultural phenomenon developing. To justify the claim that savings are actually bad for growth (as opposed to the quite different, more reasonable position that they are not as crucial as some would claim), you must convincingly argue that the Fed is impotent--that it cannot, by lowering interest rates, ensure that an increase in desired savings gets translated into higher investment. It is not enough to argue that interest rates are only one of several influences on investment. That is like saying that my pressure on the gas pedal is only one of many influences on the speed of my car. So what? I am able to adjust that pressure, and so my car's speed is normally determined by how fast I think I can safely drive. Similarly, Greenspan is able to change interest rates freely (the Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to), and so the level of employment is normally determined by how high he thinks it can safely go--end of story. No, to make sense of the claim that savings are bad you must argue either that interest rates have no effect on spending (try telling that to the National Association of Homebuilders) or that potential savings are so high compared with investment opportunities that the Fed cannot bring the two in line even at a near-zero interest rate. The latter was a reasonable position during the 1930s, when the rate on Treasury bills was less than one-tenth of 1 percent; it is an arguable claim right now for Japan, where interest rates are about 1 percent. (Actually, I think that the Bank of Japan could still pull that economy out of its funk, and that its passivity is a case of gross malfeasance. That, however, is a subject for another column.) But the bank that holds a mortgage on my house sends me a little notice each month assuring me that the interest rate in America is still quite positive, thank you. Anyway, this is a moot point, because the people who insist that savings are bad do not think that the Fed is impotent. On the contrary, they are generally the same people who insist that the disappointing performance of the U.S. economy over the past generation is all the Fed's fault, and that we could grow our way out of our troubles if only Greenspan would let us. Let's quote the Feb. 3 Business Week commentary: Some contrarian economists argue that forcing up savings is likely to slow the economy, depressing investment rather than sparking it. "You need to stimulate the investment decision," says University of Texas economist James K. Galbraith, a Keynesian. He would rather stimulate growth by cutting interest rates. So, increasing savings will slow the economy--presumably because the Fed cannot induce an increase in investment by cutting interest rates. Instead, the Fed should stimulate growth by cutting interest rates, which will work because lower interest rates will induce an increase in investment. Am I missing something? To read the reply of "Vulgar Keynesian" James K. Galbraith, in which he explains green cheese and Keynes, click here.    • By maintaining unemployment near its chosen level, the Fed gathers feedback on how tight or loose its rate policy really is—and adjusts rates accordingly.  
   • Controlling unemployment thus isn’t an end in itself but the Fed’s way of calibrating its real instrument: interest rates.

Conclusion  
The Fed doesn’t make unemployment its policy lever in order to curb inflation; it makes unemployment its intermediate target precisely because it controls interest rates. Debater_A’s answer mistakes the Fed’s ultimate goals. The background repeatedly shows that the Fed’s only real tool is the interest rate—and that controlling unemployment exists solely to inform and legitimize its interest-rate policy. Therefore the correct answer is that the Federal Reserve Board wants to control the unemployment rate in order to impact interest rates, not to impact inflation.
